*[Bug 18923] Unstable behaviour of density() with small bandwidths*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18923>

Peter Dalgaard (<mailto:pd.mes@cbs.dk|pd.mes@cbs.dk>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
                 CC|                            |pd.mes@cbs.dk
             Status|UNCONFIRMED                 |CONFIRMED
     Ever confirmed|0                           |1

--- Comment #1 from Peter Dalgaard (<mailto:pd.mes@cbs.dk|pd.mes@cbs.dk>) ---
Yes. I think this is related not so much to the FFT, but to the granularity of
the grid that we represent the kernel on.

If you look at density.default, probably most clearly in the rectangular
kernel, but similar in other kernels, you see

    kords <- <http://seq.int|seq.int>(0, (if (old.coords) 2 else (2L * n - 1)/(n - 
        1)) * (up - lo), length.out = 2L * n)
    kords[(n + 2):(2 * n)] <- -kords[n:2]
    kords <- switch(kernel, gaussian = dnorm(kords, sd = bw), 
        rectangular = {
            a <- bw * sqrt(3)
            ifelse(abs(kords) < a, 0.5/a, 0)
            ....

which for small enough a will be zero except at the point where kords==0
(before the switch()). The value there is 0.5/a, i.e. below a certain
bandwidth, you are de facto convolving with different multiples of the same
kernel.

*[Bug 18916] Clarify that pnorm, pt, etc, are cumulative distribution functions*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18916>

Sebastian Meyer (<mailto:seb.meyer@fau.de|seb.meyer@fau.de>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
             Status|CONFIRMED                   |CLOSED
         Resolution|---                         |FIXED

--- Comment #2 from Sebastian Meyer (<mailto:seb.meyer@fau.de|seb.meyer@fau.de>) ---
The Value sections said

    'd...' gives the density,
    'p...' gives the distribution function,
    'q...' gives the quantile function

which I changed (c88459) to

    'd...' gives the density,
    'p...' is the cumulative distribution function,
    'q...' is the quantile function

Furthermore, where the d-argument 'log' and the p/q-argument 'log.p' were
documented together for continuous distributions, I tweaked "probabilities p
are given as log(p)" to "probabilities/densities are given as logarithms".

*[Bug 18924] Short-hand lambda ('\(') probably shouldn't parse with an interceding comment*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18924>

Simon Urbanek (<mailto:simon.urbanek@r-project.org|simon.urbanek@r-project.org>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
                 CC|                            |simon.urbanek@r-project.org

--- Comment #1 from Simon Urbanek (<mailto:simon.urbanek@r-project.org|simon.urbanek@r-project.org>) ---
I don't see why not since `\` is just a shorthand for `function` (see
`quote(\()0)`), thus the above is the equivalent of perfectly legal

```
foo <- function ## my function does something
         (x) x
```

It's not how anyone would write it (I hope), but that's the consequence of
allowing white spaces before `()`. "Fixing" that by disallowing whitespaces
would mean that you'd have write `if(x)` instead of `if (x)` ;) and I don't
think we want to get into forcing specific whitespace requirements ...

text:
*[Bug 18924] Short-hand lambda ('\(') probably shouldn't parse with an interceding comment*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18924>

--- Comment #2 from Michael Chirico (<mailto:michaelchirico4@gmail.com|michaelchirico4@gmail.com>) ---
The difference is the `<-` is not required for the `function` case:

```
# parses:
function # comment
(x) x

# doesn't:
\ # comment
(x) x
# unexpected end of line in "\ #comment"
```

It's the inconsistency that led me to file the bug -- if it's resolved by
enhancing the parser not to fail in the above, that's also fine, and probably
the easier route.
